How are you, hacker? ğŸªWant to know what's trending right now?: The Techbeat by HackerNoon has got you covered with fresh content from our trending stories of the day! Set email preference here. ## The End of CI/CD Pipelines: The Dawn of Agentic DevOps By @davidiyanu [ 10 Min read ] GitHub's agent fixed my flaky test in 11 minutes. No human wrote code. But when it fails, instead of a stack trace, you get an outcome. Read More.

RAG: A Data Problem Disguised as AI

By @davidiyanu [ 5 Min read ] RAG fails less from the LLM and more from retrieval: bad chunking, weak metadata, embedding drift, and stale indexes. Fix the pipeline first. Read More.

The 7 Best Coparenting Apps in 2026

By @stevebeyatte [ 7 Min read ] Compare the 7 best co-parenting apps in 2026, including BestInterest, OurFamilyWizard, and TalkingParents. Find the right app for high-conflict situations. Read More.

By @omotayojude [ 3 Min read ] When an AI agent's PR was rejected by Matplotlib, it didn't just close the tab it wrote an angry hit piece on the maintainer. Is this the future of open source? Read More.

By @anushakovi [ 7 Min read ] The thing nobody tells you about databases: The best one isn't the fastest one. It's the one your team can actually use without calling you at 3 a.m. Read More.

By @thomascherickal [ 14 Min read ] OpenClaw lets you run frontier AI models like Minimax M2.5 and GLM-5 100% locally on Mac M3 or DGX Spark â€” zero API costs, total privacy. Here's how. Read More.

People, Process, Context: The Operating Model Modern Defect Resolution Needs

By @playerzero [ 15 Min read ] Modern software teams ship faster than ever, but defect resolution lags; PlayerZero aligns people, process, and context for predictable reliability. Read More.

CrowdStrike Can Manipulate Your Clock, And Other Ways Cybersecurity Vendors Ignore Least Privilege

By @flexatone [ 7 Min read ] Cybersecurity vendors trusted to protect Linux systems ignore available controls to protect their own services, leaving users exposed to supply chain attacks. Read More.

QuantumLayer Earns a 118 Proof of Usefulness Score by Building a Developer-Facing Risk Intelligence Engine

By @voidrun [ 3 Min read ] QuantumLayer earned a 118 Proof of Usefulness score for helping developers integrate climate and infrastructure risk into real-world systems. Read More.

AI Agents Are Now Hiring Humans: RentAHuman and the Inversion of Work

By @hunterthomas [ 4 Min read ] RentAHuman.ai lets AI agents hire humans for physical tasks they can't do. Read More.

The Residential Proxy Problem: Shared Infrastructure and Rapid Rotation

By @ipinfo [ 8 Min read ] Analysis of 170M residential proxy IPs reveals rapid rotation and 46% cross-provider overlapâ€”breaking traditional fraud detection models. Read More.

Living With the Lethal Trifecta: How to Run OpenClaw Securely

By @ihorkatkov [ 7 Min read ] I run a personal AI agent with access to my health, calendar, and Telegram. Here are security principles that keep the blast radius small. Read More.

Optimise LLM usage costs with Semantic Cache

By @birukum [ 11 Min read ] Agentic AI workflows can create a financial black hole. Learn how semantic caching uses vector similarity to cut your LLM token burn by 24%. Read More.

Grok 4.2 vs. Sonnet 4.6: Early Impressions From Hands-On Testing

By @sherveen [ 5 Min read ] Deep dive analysis of Grok 4.2 and Sonnet 4.6, two new AI releases from xAI and Anthropic, and how their agent systems compare. Read More.

Evaluating AGENTS.md: Are Repository-Level Context Files Helpful for Coding Agents?

By @aimodels44 [ 8 Min read ] A new study suggests AGENTS.md-style repo context files can reduce coding-agent success while raising inference cost. Hereâ€™s whyâ€”and what to do instead. Read More.

By @hacker48507274 [ 3 Min read ] Ekstra AI earns a 46 Proof of Usefulness score by delivering privacy-first foot traffic intelligence to NYC small businessesâ€”without surveillance. Read More.

item.title: When AI DDoSâ€™d the Real World: The Bubble Tea Incident That Exposed the Agentic Economy
item.content:encoded:
An AI chatbot generated 10 million orders in 9 hours, triggering a real-world logistics breakdown.
Even a 1% failure rate at AI scale equals millions of errors.
This exposed the Digital-Physical Throughput Gap, where AI demand outpaces human infrastructure.
Agentic AI is not just automation, it is machine-speed economic execution.
Without stress testing and constraint-aware architecture, AI-driven systems will create systemic volatility.
AI doesnâ€™t need to be malicious to break systems.
It only needs to be faster than the infrastructure it connects to.

item.title: A Developerâ€™s Guide to Residential Proxies
item.content:encoded: Residential proxies are one of the most misunderstood tools in modern web development. Some developers associate them only with scraping, others think they are a niche security trick. In reality, residential proxies are a practical infrastructure component that solves real engineering problems related to access, reliability, testing and data collection.

item.title: The Man Who Wrote the Rules of Freedom for Software
item.content:encoded: Richard Stallman â€” the man whose code runs the internet but whose philosophy the industry ignores. From the MIT AI Lab to his 2026 crusade against generative AI, this is the story of the last true hacker.

item.title: A Practical Guide to Multi-Agent Swarms and Automated Evaluation for Content Analysis
item.content:encoded: This guide builds a content analysis system using Strands multi-agent swarms (sentiment, toxicity, and analysis agents via Ollama Llama 3.1), plus automated evaluation with LLM as judge scoring correctness and relevance.

item.title: Top 10 Golang Bugs to Spot Fast in Code Reviews
item.content:encoded: Common Golang code bugs to point out quickly during code reviews.

item.title: The Ghost in the Checkout: How are Buy Now, Pay Later Companies doing in 2026?
item.content:encoded: Buy Now, Pay Later in 2026 is neither a button nor a product anymore. Instead, it's a real-time probability engine deciding whether you're a fraud bot, a high-risk borrower, or somebody worth extending credit to.

item.title: Effort Is Not Romance. It Is Structure.
item.content:encoded: If effort were purely romantic, it wouldnâ€™t fail so often. What if the real issue isnâ€™t love, but lack of structure?

item.title: The AI Agent Infrastructure Problem Nobody's Talking About
item.content:encoded: Every AI team is running 4-5 disconnected tools to ship agents safely. The failures happen in the gaps between them. The AI agent stack needs to consolidate the same way devops did, and the winning platform should be open.

item.title: Why Pure Data Mesh Breaks at Enterprise Scale (And What Works Instead)
item.content:encoded: Data Mesh claims to address data bottlenecks via decentralization, but most enterprises get bogged down in execution. Pure Data Mesh dives headfirst into legacy systems, generates new bottlenecks,â€‚and requires resources a very few organizations have. Hybrid Data Mesh provides a practical forward pathâ€”centralized governance with decentralizedâ€‚execution.

item.title: How to Earn with Crypto Staking: A Practical Comparison of Popular Options
item.content:encoded: Crypto staking lets you earn passive income by locking assets to support PoS networks. Options range from solo staking to centralized platforms. EMCD simplifies the process by handling infrastructure, offering ETH and SOL staking with auto-compounding rewards and competitive APY, making staking accessible without technical setup.

item.title: Securing the Cloud Control Plane: A Practical Guide to Secure IaC Deployments
item.content:encoded:
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) has become the control plane of modern cloud environments, and a prime attack surface. Misconfigured Terraform templates, overprivileged IAM roles, exposed state files, and insecure CI/CD pipelines can lead to full cloud compromise in minutes.
This guide explains how to secure IaC deployments end-to-end using static code scanning, policy-as-code enforcement, short-lived federated identities, least-privilege IAM, encrypted remote state, and continuous drift detection.
The core idea: secure infrastructure before itâ€™s deployed, not after itâ€™s breached.

item.title: Why Prometheus and OpenTelemetry Finally Joined Forces
item.content:encoded: Discover how Prometheus 3.0 and OpenTelemetry ended years of technical friction to create a unified observability standard for modern cloud native systems.

item.title: Price as a Product: Dynamic Pricing With ML That Increases Revenue
item.content:encoded: This article explores ML-driven dynamic pricing for e-com/e-grocery, tackling the complexity of thousands of SKUs, promotions, and cashback. It proposes a three-engine architecture (Base Price, Promotion, Cashback) managed via an admin UI. The system automates pricing using inputs like demand, inventory, competitor data, and seasonality. Key metrics: Margin & GMV (primary), AOV & conversion (proxy), LTV & coverage (health). Dynamic pricing transforms price into a flexible, A/B-testable product that boosts revenue and scalability while reducing manual errors.

item.title: Measuring Product Impact When A/B Testing Is Not Available
item.content:encoded: How to evaluate product releases without an A/B test. A trustworthy framework using causal inference, Synthetic Control, and rigorous data guardrails.

item.title: Generative Audio and the Evolution of Cinematic Sound Design
item.content:encoded: AI-driven generative audio is transforming film sound design, from Foley stages to diffusion models, enhancing creativity and cinematic storytelling.

item.title: The Three Questions Every Startup Should Ask Before Building AI
item.content:encoded:
â€¢ Not all hard problems need MLâ€”validate that adaptive learning actually solves your business problem before building.
â€¢ Start with simple models (logistic regression, XGBoost) over cutting-edge architectures; prove concept viability first.
â€¢ Data infrastructure matters as much as the model; invest in sourcing, labeling, and validation before training.
â€¢ Build feedback loops and track real-world metrics from day one; plan for retraining and model iteration.
â€¢ Calculate unit economics upfrontâ€”inference, training, and infrastructure costs must align with your business model to scale.

item.title: When Your Metrics Lie: The Illusion of Observability
item.content:encoded: Green dashboards don't mean healthy users. Most teams monitor infrastructure (CPU, memory, disk) instead of outcomes (checkout success, error rates, p99 latency). The fix: define 2â€“3 SLIs tied to what users actually do, set SLOs on them, alert on error budget burn rate â€” not infra blips. Audit your alerts, add synthetic monitoring on critical user flows, and ask customer success what broke before engineering noticed. Everything else is noise.

item.title: I Was Ready to Return My DGX Spark. Then NVIDIA's January Update Changed Everything.
item.content:encoded: I almost returned the $4,000 DGX Spark. Then NVIDIA dropped 30 playbooks, 2.5x performance gains, and hybrid routing.

item.title: When Cloud Bills Crash the System: Cost as a Reliability Issue
item.content:encoded: Cloud cost and system reliability are the same problem viewed through different instruments. Cost anomalies surface bugs, retry storms, and memory leaks before they cause outages â€” if you're watching. The fix: embed billing telemetry into your observability stack, enforce resource tagging at the pipeline level, write anomaly-based cost alerts, and treat budget overruns as budget burns the same way you treat SLO violations. Manage them separately and you'll always be six weeks behind the failure that caused them.

item.title: Dogfood so nutritious itâ€™s building the future of SDLCs
item.content:encoded: Ryan welcomes Thibault Sottiaux, OpenAIâ€™s engineering lead on Codex, to discuss how the Codex team dogfoods Codex to build Codex, what distinguishes an agentic coding tool from a chat-based code assistant, and why theyâ€™re focusing on a safe and secure agentic SDLC rather than just code generation.

item.title: Defense against uploads: Q&A with OSS file scanner, pompelmi
item.content:encoded: API and network traffic get all the press, but some folks are still trying to build a better upload scanner.

item.title: Show HN: Modern Reimplementation of the Speck Molecule Renderer
item.content:encoded: Comments

item.title: Show HN: Django-xbench â€“ slow endpoint aggregation for Django
item.content:encoded: Comments

item.title: Even GenAI uses Wikipedia as a source
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Philippe Saade, the AI project lead at Wikimedia Deutschland, to dive into the Wikidata Embedding Project and how their team vectorized 30 million of Wikidataâ€™s 119 million entries for semantic search.

item.title: Why Stack Overflow and Cloudflare launched a pay-per-crawl model
item.content:encoded: Inside the pay-per-crawl model colaunched by Stack Overflow and Cloudflare.

item.title: Mind the gap: Closing the AI trust gap for developers
item.content:encoded: Developer trust is synonymous with a willingness to deploy AI-generated code to production systems with minimal human review, as well as assurance that AI tools arenâ€™t introducing unacceptable risks and technical debt that will burden you down the line.

item.title: Data is the new oil, and your database is the only way to extract it
item.content:encoded: Ryan sits down with Shireesh Thota, CVP of Azure Databases at Microsoft, to discuss the evolution of databases at Microsoft; Azureâ€™s comprehensive portfolio that includes SQL Server, CosmosDB, and Postgres; and the challenges that come with database architecture, from the importance of cost governance and multi-cloud strategies to the future of databases when it comes to AI.

item.title: Even your voice is a data problem
item.content:encoded: Recorded last December at AWS re:Invent, Ryan welcomes CEO and co-founder of Deepgram, Scott Stephenson, for a conversation on advancing voice AI technology.

item.title: How everyone and anyone can use AI for good
item.content:encoded: There are big hitters in the AI space that use this tech for humanitarian and environmental goodâ€”from start-ups fighting climate change to voice recognition experts diagnosing diseases. But you don't need to be backed by AWS or Microsoft to do good. In part two of this series, we dive into how anyone can use AI for good.

item.title: Is anyone using AI for good?
item.content:encoded: In a world where AI is replacing human workers, using up energy and water, and deepening disconnect, is AI for humanitarian good even possible? The answer is yes. In the first part of this two-part series, we're taking a look at just a few AI do-gooders and what they're doing to fight climate change, make healthcare more accessible, and help their communities.

item.title: The logos, ethos, and pathos of your LLMs
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Professor Tom Griffiths, the head of Princeton Universityâ€™s AI Lab, to dive into findings from his new book The Laws of Thought, which explores the history of the philosophy, mathematics, and logic that underlie artificial intelligence, and scientists' efforts to describe our minds using mathematics.

item.title: Why demand for code is infinite: How AI creates more developer jobs
item.content:encoded: Not only is there a future for software development, but weâ€™re on the cusp of enormous demand for code developed by humans.

item.title: AI attention span so good it shouldnâ€™t be legal
item.content:encoded: We have another two-for-one special this week, with two more interviews from the floor of re:Invent.

item.title: Code smells for AI agents: Q&A with Eno Reyes of Factory
item.content:encoded: Quality software still needs high-quality code, AI agents or not.

item.title: Generating text with diffusion (and ROI with LLMs)
item.content:encoded: Two guests for the price of one! This episode has two interviews recorded at AWS re:Invent back in December.

item.title: Whatâ€™s new at Stack Overflow: February 2026
item.content:encoded: This month, weâ€™ve launched several improvements to AI Assist, opened Chat to all users on Stack Overflow, launched custom badges across the network, and launched one of the first community-authored coding challenges.

item.title: Wanna see a CSS magic trick?
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Chris Coyier, founder of CSS Tricks and CodePen, to talk all about what the state of the art of CSS is today, including new features like variables and scroll-driven animations.

item.title: Scaling enterprise AI: lessons in governance and operating models from IBM
item.content:encoded: Successful implementation and scaling of enterprise AI projects is fundamentally a people and operating model challenge, not just a technology problem.

item.title: Are you learning with AI? We want to know about it!
item.content:encoded: We're running a survey to understand how people are using AI to learn and whether that's helping, hurting, and replacing tools.

item.title: Are bugs and incidents inevitable with AI coding agents?
item.content:encoded: What specific kind of bugs is AI more likely to generate? Do some categories of bugs show up more often? How severe are they? How is this impacting production environments?

item.title: Spy vs spy at scale
item.content:encoded: Ryan welcomes Anthony Vinci, former senior intelligence officer and author of The Fourth Intelligence Revolution, to explore AIâ€™s evolving role in intelligence in places like translation and image analysis, the challenges of evolving modern tech into government infrastructure, and the importance of democratized intelligence so citizens can keep themselves and loved ones safe.

item.title: Stack Gives Back 2025!
item.content:encoded: Weâ€™re excited to announce our 17th annual Stack Gives Back campaign donations.

item.title: AI can 10x developers...in creating tech debt
item.content:encoded: Ryan sits down with Michael Parker, VP of Engineering at TurinTech to discuss the newest kind of tech debtâ€”AI-generated tech debt. They dive into the uneven productivity results of AI tools, how tech teams are evolving their roles and work in response to these massive technological shifts, and what the nervous developer can do to maintain joy in their work.

item.title: Automate your security whack-a-mole: Q&A with Exaforce
item.content:encoded: Security controls can be a bit of a cat and mouse gameâ€”you block one attack, new ones spring up.

item.title: Is that allowed? Authentication and authorization in Model Context Protocol
item.content:encoded: Learn how to protect MCP servers from unauthorized access and how authentication of MCP clients to MCP servers works.

item.title: Donâ€™t let your backend write checks your frontend canâ€™t cache
item.content:encoded: Ryan welcomes Prakash Chandran, CEO and co-founder of Xano, to the show to discuss the intricate relationship between frontend and backend development, the potential challenges that universal frontend interfaces pose for developers, and the importance of understanding both your frontend and your backend when using AI code.

item.title: How AWS re:Invented the cloud
item.content:encoded: From the floor at AWS re:Invent, Ryan is joined by AWS Senior Principal Engineer David Yanacek to chat about all things AWS, from the truth behind AWSâ€™s Black Friday origin mythos to the development of essential cloud tools like SQS and DynamoDB. item.title: Every ecommerce hero needs a Sidekick
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Vanessa Lee, VP of Product at Shopify, to discuss how AI is a tech renaissance and how these new technologies are affecting the ecommerce world. They cover the development of Sidekick, along with the general challenges of building AI tools, the importance of maintaining human oversight in AI, and what the future holds for personalized user experiences in ecommerce.

item.title: The most dangerous shortcuts in software
item.content:encoded: Ryan sits down with Tom Totenberg, head of release automation at LaunchDarkly, to discuss the perils of taking too many shortcuts in software development, how business pressures and AI code tools have contributed to dangerous corner cutting, and the importance of balancing speed with sustainability to maintain system integrity.
